p: First isolated in 1947 from a rhesus macaque in Uganda, Zika virus (ZIKV) was largely ignored until 2015 when a large outbreak of ZIKV infections in Brazil was linked to a dramatic increase in microcephaly cases [ 1– 6]. ZIKV has a number of unexpected attributes for an arthropod-borne virus (“arbovirus”). In addition to the unusual propensity of ZIKV to cause microcephaly and other births defects, ZIKV can be transmitted sexually and has been shown to persist in the male and female reproductive systems [ 7– 12].
